Description: Greek terracotta of a bull. Fragment of a terracotta figure group of Europa and the Bull. The bull is charging to the right. Europa would be seated on the bull, but only her right hand is preserved. Mould-made and hollow. Rather plain back. Traces of white coating. Soft, fine orange fabric with fine white and rare silver mica inclusions and a soapy texture.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Listed in Hogarth's box lists for 1903 (that arrived in Oxford) in Box IV.5 as coming from the Hellenion. Early 4th century BC 'Attic' parallel found in Cyrenaica, of different mould series, but a similar fabric (Higgins 1970, no. 720; GR 1868,1020.46.a). A mid 5th century Boeotian terracotta also depicting this scene is known (GR 1891,0110.2). The fabric is consistent with East Greek figurines known from Rhodes.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.357) (Phase 3)
